moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Be7 8. Qf3 Qc7 9. O-O-O Nbd7 10. Bd3 h6 11. Bh4 g5
comment: A very typical and well regarded idea in the Najdorf.  The position is not the same, but the basic outline in both cases is - we are dealing with a fight for the e5-square.  What is interesting in this case is that white is successful and in a convincing way.  Admittedly there is a concrete mistake around move 20 by black before he can be overcome, but you have to realize that HE LOST PLAYING COMPLETELY PLAUSIBLE MOVES.  I.e., the only mistake he made was only a mistake because of the sophisticated way white punished it in this game.  You can't ask for more than that!

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Be7 8. Qf3 Qc7 9. O-O-O Nbd7 10. Bd3 h6 11. Bh4 g5 12. fxg5 Ne5 13. Qe2 Nfg4 14. Nf3
comment: This is the correct plan - to put every resource towards overcoming the e5-square.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Be7 8. Qf3 Qc7 9. O-O-O Nbd7 10. Bd3 h6 11. Bh4 g5 12. fxg5 Ne5 13. Qe2 Nfg4 14. Nf3 Nxf3 15. gxf3 hxg5 16. Bg3 Ne5 17. Qf2
comment: A very classical, straightforward approach to the position.  White is going to play h4 which opens the h-file (benefitting him because he has a lead in development and can swing his rooks across the first rank) and, more importantly fights for e5 by knocking out the props from under it.  After the g5-pawn goes then f3-f4 is coming.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Be7 8. Qf3 Qc7 9. O-O-O Nbd7 10. Bd3 h6 11. Bh4 g5 12. fxg5 Ne5 13. Qe2 Nfg4 14. Nf3 Nxf3 15. gxf3 hxg5 16. Bg3 Ne5 17. Qf2 Bd7 18. h4 O-O-O 19. hxg5

1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Be7 8. Qf3 Qc7 9. O-O-O Nbd7 10. Bd3 h6 11. Bh4 g5 12. fxg5 Ne5 13. Qe2 Nfg4 14. Nf3 Nxf3 15. gxf3 hxg5 16. Bg3 Ne5 17. Qf2 Bd7 18. h4 O-O-O 19. hxg5 Bxg5+ 20. Kb1 Nxd3
comment: I think this may be black's only mistake in the whole game.  Apparently, it gets out of the way of the coming f4-fork and would have to be played anyway.  Furthermore, I think it might have been hard for black to imagine how he could possibly be worse in the resulting position.  But he is a lot worse and that's why the game is so interesting.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Be7 8. Qf3 Qc7 9. O-O-O Nbd7 10. Bd3 h6 11. Bh4 g5 12. fxg5 Ne5 13. Qe2 Nfg4 14. Nf3 Nxf3 15. gxf3 hxg5 16. Bg3 Ne5 17. Qf2 Bd7 18. h4 O-O-O 19. hxg5 Bxg5+ 20. Kb1 Nxd3 21. cxd3 Kb8 22. Rhg1 Be7
comment: How can white be better?! The only thing to choose between is the minors; white's g3-B is active, but black has the two Bs...

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Be7 8. Qf3 Qc7 9. O-O-O Nbd7 10. Bd3 h6 11. Bh4 g5 12. fxg5 Ne5 13. Qe2 Nfg4 14. Nf3 Nxf3 15. gxf3 hxg5 16. Bg3 Ne5 17. Qf2 Bd7 18. h4 O-O-O 19. hxg5 Bxg5+ 20. Kb1 Nxd3 21. cxd3 Kb8 22. Rhg1 Be7 23. Rc1 Qa5 24. Qe3
comment: Aha! Black's king is also slightly weak, and the simple idea of Bf2 will create more weaknesses. 5... a6 is coming back to haunt him.

Qc7+ Ka8 34. Bxb6
comment: An extremely pleasant riposte to the positional agony of last week's game.
